title: Popularity Re-Ranking
summary:
# Managing Popularity Bias in Recommender Systems

This academic paper addresses a fundamental problem in recommendation algorithms: the tendency to over-recommend popular items while neglecting niche products in the long tail. The authors propose a personalized diversification re-ranking approach that can be applied as a post-processing step to any recommender system output.

## The Popularity Bias Problem

Recommender systems often suffer from popularity bias, where collaborative filtering algorithms emphasize popular items—those with more ratings—over less popular alternatives. This creates a self-reinforcing cycle where popular items receive more recommendations, generating more ratings, while genuinely interesting niche products remain hidden. The paper illustrates this with the long-tail distribution: the top 20% of items by popularity accumulate the majority of ratings, leaving 80% of items in what researchers call the long tail. These underrepresented items are precisely the products users are least likely to discover on their own, making them critical for businesses seeking to expand customer discovery.

## The xQuAD-Based Solution

The authors adapt the xQuAD (Explicit Query Aspect Diversification) framework from information retrieval to the popularity bias problem. Their approach works as a post-processing step that re-ranks any base recommendation list according to a scoring function balancing accuracy against diversity. The core equation combines the predicted user interest in an item with a diversity term that promotes items from underrepresented categories, controlled by a lambda parameter.

Two variants are introduced: Binary xQuAD performs minimal re-ranking by simply inserting the best long-tail item where possible, while Smooth xQuAD computes the ratio of items in each popularity category to encourage more diverse coverage. A key innovation is personalization—the algorithm adjusts the diversity bonus based on each user's historical interest in long-tail items, recognizing that some users prefer popular mainstream content while others appreciate niche recommendations.

## Evaluation Methodology

The researchers tested their approach on MovieLens 1M (approximately 1 million movie ratings) and Epinions (consumer opinion reviews) datasets, filtering to include only users with at least 20 ratings and removing distant tail items with fewer than 20 ratings. They compared four algorithms: the RankALS baseline, a regularization-based long-tail method (LT-Reg), and both Binary and Smooth xQuAD re-ranking variants. The evaluation employed multiple metrics including Average Recommendation Popularity (ARP), Average Percentage of Long Tail items (APLT), Average Coverage of Long Tail items (ACLT), and NDCG for ranking accuracy.

## Key Findings

The experiments revealed that re-ranking methods substantially outperform the regularization approach at promoting long-tail items while maintaining acceptable accuracy loss. On the sparser Epinions dataset, both xQuAD variants achieved around 15% long-tail catalog exposure with 10% NDCG loss, compared to the baseline near zero. The MovieLens results showed even stronger performance, with Smooth xQuAD demonstrating particular advantage in catalog-wide coverage. A notable finding was that ARP alone is insufficient for evaluating long-tail promotion—algorithms can have similar ARP scores while differing dramatically in their actual coverage of niche items. This demonstrates why multiple metrics are necessary to properly assess popularity bias mitigation.

## Implications and Conclusions

The paper concludes that adequate long-tail coverage is essential for business success since popular items are already well-known to most users, making the ability to recommend beyond this band critical for introducing users to new products. The proposed re-ranking approach offers flexibility through the lambda parameter, allowing system designers to tune the accuracy-diversity trade-off based on business needs. The authors note that this method could extend to multi-stakeholder recommendation scenarios where different groups need balanced representation, and they emphasize using multiple metrics—APLT, ACLT alongside ARP—to properly evaluate long-tail promotion effectiveness.
